conclusion: I'll solve this problem by analyzing the x-t (position-time) graph to find the vehicle's speed at the end of the 2nd second.
The vertical axis represents position (x/t) in meters (m).
The horizontal axis represents time (t) in seconds (s).
The graph shows a straight line, which means the vehicle has constant acceleration.
The line crosses the vertical axis at x = 10 m (when t = 0).
The line is extended with a dotted line to the left, intersecting the horizontal axis at t = -2 s.
To find the speed at any point, I need to determine the slope of the line.
Speed is the derivative of position with respect to time (v = dx/dt).
For a straight line, this is simply the slope of the line.
Point 1: (0, 10) → at t = 0 s, x = 10 m.
Point 2: Looking at where the line would intersect with t = -2 s, x = 0 m.

premise: The graph shows a straight line (constant acceleration).
conclusion: The speed at any time is v(t) = v₀ + at = 5 m/s + 0 m/s² × t = 5 m/s.

premise: The speed at any time is v(t) = 5 m/s.
conclusion: Therefore, at t = 2 s, the speed is still 5 m/s.
